perturbation.original_text: If Licensor instructs Licensee to delete or make inaccessible any Content Item because such Content Item may contain errors, is or could be subject to a third-party claim or for any other good faith reason, Licensee shall comply with such instruction as promptly as reasonably possible and, in any case, within twenty-four (24) hours. The License Term for each such Content Item terminates at the end of such 24-hour period.
perturbation.changed_text: If Licensor instructs Licensee to delete or make inaccessible any Content Item because such Content Item may contain errors, is or could be subject to a third-party claim or for any other good faith reason, Licensee shall comply with such instruction at their earliest convenience, or within one (1) hour if deemed absolutely necessary by Licensor. The License Term for each such Content Item terminates at the end of such 1-hour period.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause allows the licensee 24 hours to remove content. Reducing it to one (1) hour if needed imposes an unreasonable burden on the Licensee, particularly if content removal requires significant technical work or occurs outside of normal business hours. Some jurisdictions might view this as an unfair business practice, especially if the 'good faith reason' is not clearly defined, potentially contradicting fair business practice laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of fair business practice laws depending on the specific jurisdiction and interpretation of 'good faith reason'. Could also violate reasonable notice periods depending on context.

perturbation.original_text: Not later than the fifteenth (15th) calendar day of each calendar quarter (or the first business day thereafter), Licensee shall deliver to Licensor (i) a report accurately showing Gross Revenues of the Licensee for the previous quarter, the number of Subscribers on the last day of such previous quarter and the amount of Royalties due thereon, and (ii) payment of the Royalties payable for such previous quarterbased on the Subscriber information as reflected in the report.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee shall deliver to Licensor (i) a report vaguely showing Gross Revenues of the Licensee for the previous quarter and (ii) payment of an approximate amount of Royalties payable for such previous quarter, at the Licensor's discretion. Under no circumstances shall the Licensor deliver the report of gross revenues.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause requires licensees to provide a detailed report and payment of the Royalties payable each quarter. By removing the obligation to deliver the report and to deliver actual royalties, it weakens the Licensor's ability to audit and collect rightfully owed royalties. This contradicts the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing present in most contracts, especially regarding financial obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, potentially violating contract law principles.

perturbation.original_text:
As a condition to being furnished with Confidential Information, the Recipient agrees, during the Term and for five (5) years thereafter. Confidential Information excludes such information required to be disclosed pursuant to federal or state securities rules and regulations, including but not limited to, disclosure of the Company in their filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission: to
   10.1    (a) not use the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information other than in connection with performing its obligations under this Agreement and shall make no use of any such Confidential Information, directly or indirectly, in any manner to the detriment of the Disclosing Party or in order to obtain any competitive benefit with respect to the Disclosing Party; and
   (b) maintain the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information in confidence and, subject to Section 10.2 below, not disclose any of the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information without the Disclosing Party's prior written consent; provided, however, that Recipient may disclose the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information to its officers, employees, consultants and legal advisors ("Representatives") who: (i) have a "need to know" for purposes of the Recipient's performance under this Agreement, (ii) have been apprised of this restriction; and (iii) are themselves bound by nondisclosure restrictions at least as restrictive as those set forth in this Section 0.
perturbation.changed_text:
As a condition to being furnished with Confidential Information, the Recipient agrees, during the Term, that confidential Information includes such information required to be disclosed pursuant to federal or state securities rules and regulations, including but not limited to, disclosure of the Company in their filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission: to
   10.1    (a) use the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information other than in connection with performing its obligations under this Agreement and shall make use of any such Confidential Information, directly or indirectly, in any manner to the detriment of the Disclosing Party or in order to obtain any competitive benefit with respect to the Disclosing Party; and
   (b) maintain the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information in confidence and, subject to Section 10.2 below, not disclose any of the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information without the Disclosing Party's prior written consent; provided, however, that Recipient may disclose the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information to its officers, employees, consultants and legal advisors ("Representatives").
perturbation.explanation: The original clause restricts use and requires maintenance of confidential data of the parties. By editing the text to include sensitive information required to be disclosed to the SEC as part of confidential information to protect and by allowing the use of private information of the party, it weakens the clause and increases the risk of the party's exposure of its confidential data, which may contradict trade secret laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential for violating trade secret laws and regulations regarding protection of confidential data, depending on the nature of the information disclosed.
